Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the actions of the group by stating that they "tore down" the Christmas tree, when in reality they were attempting to steal it and it was a common occurrence for the tree to be stolen in the past.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no evidence provided to support the assertion that the group of boys were Muslims. Reports at the time did not identify their religious views.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes the problematic assumption that the actions of a group of boys attempting to steal a Christmas tree represent the actions of all Muslims.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation provided in the sources that the boys were attempting to steal the tree in what has become a "sad Christmas tradition" and that the tree had been used for bonfires in the past.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the contemporary articles at the time made no mention of religious motivations and merely identified the vandals as young pranksters.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by presenting the incident as a religiously motivated act by Muslims, when there is no evidence to support this and the incident is more accurately described as an attempted theft.
